nealrichardson commented on pull request #5840: ARROW-7172: [C++][Dataset] Improve format of Expression::ToString
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5840#discussion_r346561712
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/dataset/filter.cc
 ##########
 @@ -559,43 +558,35 @@ struct ScalarExpressionToString {
 };
 
 std::string ScalarExpression::ToString() const {
+  auto type_repr = value_->type->ToString();
 
 Review comment:
   IDK that including this type is worthwhile (or if you think it is, then I probably want a different, simple print method that doesn't include it)

bkietz commented on pull request #5840: ARROW-7172: [C++][Dataset] Improve format of Expression::ToString
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5840#discussion_r346944486
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/dataset/filter.cc
 ##########
 @@ -559,43 +558,35 @@ struct ScalarExpressionToString {
 };
 
 std::string ScalarExpression::ToString() const {
+  auto type_repr = value_->type->ToString();
 
 Review comment:
   Even with implicit casts, the precise type of a scalar in an expression is significant. Notably: without implicit casts `"b"_ > 4:int32` might be invalid where `"b"_ > 4:float64` is not. If you're looking at these strings trying to debug a casting error, you really need the type information for the scalars. IMHO, it's out of scope to provide a print function without this; it seems like you might be planning to use these for something other than debugging (like direct re-evaluation in R, maybe)?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

 Review comment:
   I wasn't planning on that, no. My intended use case was more "what is in this object anyway?" and not "why did my object not evaluate?".

pitrou commented on pull request #5840: ARROW-7172: [C++][Dataset] Improve format of Expression::ToString
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5840#discussion_r347847655
 
 

 ##########
 File path: r/tests/testthat/test-expression.R
 ##########
 @@ -54,9 +54,7 @@ test_that("C++ expressions", {
   expect_is(!(f < 4), "NotExpression")
   expect_output(
     print(f > 4),
-    # We can do better than this right?
-    # TODO: re-add the detail after ARROW-7172
-    'ComparisonExpression', #\nGREATER(field(f), scalar<double>(4))',
+    'ComparisonExpression\n(f > 4:double)',
 
 Review comment:
   Why the `\n` by the way? It tends to make output more verbose and (IMHO) less readable in a prompt such as IPython.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: Instead of {{GREATER(FIELD(b), SCALAR<int32>(3))}}, these could just read {{"b"_ > int32(3)}}
